_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Sounty County R.O. Plant utilizes chlorine gas in the disinfection process of treating potable water. Due to the inherent dangers in handling chlorine a prevention program has been established to reduce the risk to employees and the public. This program is comprised of several individual elements all of which are designed with the intent of preventing a chlorine gas release. At this plant the two individual chlorine systems are similar in that identical equipment is used and procedures are the same. They are both in the same location but different injection points are used, therefore they will be considered as the same process. All prevention program elements are in place for each system. The individual elements of the program are as follows.
1. Process Hazard Analysis.(PHA)
A PHA was conducted on 4/7/99 and 4/8/99 at the South County Plant. This analysis determined the hazards present and recommendations were made to reduce the risks associated with the chlorine gas process.
2.  Operating Procedures.
A written set of procedures has been developed to guide the operators of the system on how to startup, shutdown and normally operate the system. Procedures have also been developed to operate in either temporary or emergency conditions. The procedures cover operating limitations, safety and health considerations.
3.  Training.
All operators receive initial training on the system and periodic training or refresher training to keep current with procedures and equipment. Each operator is trained with regard to the process, limitations, emergency response procedures, hazards and accepted work practices. All operators are tested to verify knowledge of the above.
4.  Mechanical Integrity
This program documents the maintenance and inspection portion of the program. It insures that proper construction and materials have been used in installations with hazardous materials.
5.  Management of Change.
Any change in the process, from materials to procedures, most undergo an evaluation or review prior to implementing in order to prevent accidents. Any changes must be documented.
6.  Prestartup Review.
Although similar to management of change, this element is designed more towards new or modified processes. The new process undergoes a review to insure design specifications meet applicable codes and construction meet standards.
7.  Compliance Audits
Audits are conducted every three years to verify that  program elements are in place and being implemented.
8.  Incident Investigations.
Any incident that may have resulted in an emergency situation will be reviewed. This investigation may include corrective action, communication to staff and documentation of all findings.
9.  Employee Participation.
All employees will have access to the RMP information and are encouraged to participate in the decision making process.
10.  Hot Work Permit.
Any welding or brazing process near a regulated process must be formally authorized and permitted.
11.  Contractors.
Before contractor selection, an evaluation of the contractors' safety program must be completed. Contractors safety performance must be demonstrated through injury logs, training programs, etc.  A well defined procedure explaining contractor responsibilities concerning emergency action procedures must be followed.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
In this water treatment facility we handle chlorine, considered a hazardous chemical by the Environmental Protection Agency. The same properties that make chlorine valuable as a commodity also make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling chlorine to prevent unnecessary exposure, reduce the threat to the community and co-workers. It is our policy to adhere to applicable Federal, State and Local rules and regulations. Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle chlorine, safety devices in the design of the facility, safe handling procedures and training of personnel

Our emergency response program is based upon the facility's chlorine standard operating procedures, emergency procedures and the Indian River County Emergency Plan for Hazardous materials. The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire authority and notification of the potentially affected neighbors.

The stationary source and regulated substance handled.
The primary purpose of this facility is to provide potable water to the surrounding community. Chlorine is used during the treatment process to disinfect the water. Chlorine gas cylinders are delivered to the plant by semi truck and unloaded by the truck crane where plant operators then load the cylinders by stationary crane, onto a scale. The cranes are tested and certified on an annual basis. Plant personnel are the only authorized individuals to enter the area. The facility currently has an inventory of 10,000 lbs of chlorine.

Worst case release scenario.
The worst case of a chlorine leak would be a complete failure of 2  1-ton cylinders. The release would be the entire contents or 4,000 lbs. in a ten minute period.  It is assumed that all chlorine released will be in a gaseous form.

The alternate release scenario
The alternate release scenario is one in which a more likely type of failure could occur. For this facility it would involve a vacuum line break.

Accidental Release preventi

on program.
This water treatment facility does comply with the EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and  applicable State codes and regulations. The recommendations as set forth in the chlorine institute manual are strictly adhered to.

Five Year Accident History
No accidental releases of chlorine have occurred at this facility.

Emergency Response Program
The program at this facility is based upon the plant's standard operating procedures and the Indian River County's Emergency Plan for Hazardous Materials. The Indian River County Emergency Services Division will be conducting release drills on a biannual basis.

Planned changes to improve safety.
Periodic reviews and evaluations by plant staff and engineers insure up to date procedures and equipment. Currently, Indian River County Utility Services is conducting a feasibility study to determine the possible use of an alternate form of water disinfection.
